text: We have just returned from a three week stay at the Heritance Hotel. Hotel was basically good, everything worked, including the staff who, if anything, could be overly attentive. Rooms were stylish, had plenty of storage space and were serviced twice daily. Balconies had views across the beach to the setting sun. Some guests complained of minor faults, e.g. our fridge broke down but was repaired the same morning. Food was a good as could be expected with Buffet Service and we were never bored, although the dining room could be noisy. The hotel is proud of its swimming pools and rightly so. Attentive pool boys and life guards ensure there is not the usual scramble for beds and towels. We actually preferred the second (residents) pool to that shown in all the literature. The beach was regularly cleaned and patrolled. Constant slight surf, no problems for even moderate swimmers but small children should be supervised. The hotel‚Äôs main drawback is its isolation. Locally, there is simply nowhere to go and little to do. Ahungalla village consists of some 70 yards of dilapidated shacks selling local produce and a few basics at blatantly ‚Äôtourist‚Äô and local prices. There is also a passable bakery, a pharmacy, a bank with no ATM and a railway station at which few trains actually stop. There are two bus services and two qualities of bus i.e. Air Conditioned and Local. It is difficult to ascertain what is a public bus, as opposed to touring or private hire and even more difficult to have them stop. Heritance guests are not expected to want to walk anywhere, let alone get on a bus. The weather was good. It rained frequently but usually in late evening and accompanied by spectacular lightning. Mosquitoes are in evidence and, despite a wall plug device and sprays we were both bitten frequently. Guests attempting to leave the hotel by the main entrance have to run the gauntlet of a persistent group of motorised tricycle (Tuk Tuk) taxi drivers who will resort to any device to have you hire them. In addition, the driver will insist on waiting for you and interfere with your activities. Their constant attentions became oppressive, more so than had we stayed in Bentota or Hikkaduwa where there are more hotels, more activities, thereby more tourists to go around. Beach vendors were a nuisance but were not permitted onto hotel premises. A fellow female guests was accosted on the beach some 200yds from the hotel and robbed of her hat and wrap. This was however an isolated incident and we found the local people welcoming and keen to promote their countries new found stability. Expeditions were possible, 400 yards North along the beach to a fish restaurant shack is worthwhile. I ordered Lobster and drank a local beer whist two young men went out with snorkels and a net to retrieve one. 800yds south along the Galle road, on the left, is the Lucky Lanka Spice Garden and Ayurvidic Centre run by a charming young man. Full body massage for ¬£10 and a large selection of herbal potions to buy at ‚Äòlocal‚Äô prices. Other worthwhile excursions are a tour of lagoon at Balapitaya (or Bentota) with a visit to one island to see cinnamon being hand rolled by a wonderful old man and his elfin grand daughter. A morning‚Äôs snorkelling by Some at International Dive Centre, located at Coral Sands Hotel in Hikkaduwa is good value where there is an excellent parade of fish, including Octopus. The coral was badly damaged in the Tsunami but hopefully showing signs of a return. If Temples and/or elephants are your thing, then there are further trips afield, e.g Kandy, Yala National Park and Burwela Bird Sanctuary. However, from Ahungalla, both entail an expenditure of over ¬£110 pp, an overnight stay and between 5-7 hours in a minivan, each way. In summary; great hotel but we chose the wrong location for the type of holiday we enjoy. To get the best from Sri Lanka we would recommend dividing time between the Highlands, forests, wildlife parks and beaches. If however, you want a hotel based beach stay for a few days, you would be pushed to find better. Sri Lanka has great potential, stunning scenery, culture, a vibrant history and the most glorious beaches I have seen.

text: Have just returned from 2 weeks at the Heritance and overall it was a disappointing experience, primarily because the service was so mixed, ranging from good, to indifferent, to frankly poor. My wife and I travelled with our 13 year old son, and we stayed in 2 adjacent luxury rooms, which were slightly tired, but extremely spacious, and thoroughly cleaned every day. A word of warning to anyone travelling with younger children, we had made 3 advance requests via our Tour Operator "Kuoni", for inter connecting rooms. We received no reply, and were only advised on arrival that the hotel has no interconnecting rooms. The 2 hotel pools are large and well maintained, one offering some limited organised activities and the other residents' pool offering a quieter option. The hotel and grounds are spacious, and even though the hotel was fully occupied for part of our stay, it never felt over crowded. We had opted for bed and breakfast, so didn't experience the buffet, all inclusive option. However a few of our fellow guests did and commented that the food was good quality, but repetitive if staying for 2 weeks. We mainly ate in the Coffee Shop restaurant where the food was good, and given a supposed 5 star hotel, we thought the prices were reasonable. Dining out options in the village of Ahungalla are non existent. If you walk out of the hotel complex, you are quickly surrounded by several locals, offering TukTuk rides, boat safaris, and numerous trips. They are persistent but never threatening, and several firm " no thank you" will usually see them retreat. The village does have a pharmacy and a bank. If you are cashing travellers cheques, it is worth the 5 minute stroll to the bank as it offers a significantly better exchange rate than the hotel. For dining out you need to get a taxi or a TukTuk to Bentota or else to HIkkaduwa. Bentota has several hotels and is 20 minutes in a taxi or about 25/30 minutes in a TukTuk. The drivers will wait for you and negotiate a return trip price. A hotel taxi was about ¬£20 for a return trip, with the tuktuks costing about half of that. The best restaurant we found was the Golden Grill, good for curries and seafood. Dinner for 3 people with beer and soft drinks was typically ¬£30 to ¬£40 in total. Main frustration came with the inconsistent service in the hotel. At breakfast, there was a great range of food, and all well presented, and plenty of staff on hand. Unfortunately it wasn't unusual for 3 different waiters to approach you to ask whether we wanted tea or coffee, but then none of them would get round to serving it. The pool attendants are helpful but want tipping continually and the room cleaners changed several times and all made subtle overtures for tips. Reception staff were always smiling, but poorly trained and inefficient with simple requests having to be made several times before anything got done. After the first week we found a great guy working reception and just made sure we dealt with him. Some lovely staff serving drinks around the pool, always friendly and helpful. Wandering onto the beach is spoilt because the locals will lie in wait and then follow you round trying to sell you gouges or trips. They will ask your name and if you give it, they will stand at the edge of the hotel property calling to you while you try and relax on your sun bed. Again they aren't threatening in any way, just persistent and something of a pain. Just keep saying "no thank you" and they will eventually give up ! Overall, the Heritance is nice but dated hotel, but represents pretty reasonable value for what it is. The location is isolated but the grounds and pools are good, and the rooms are fine. It has the potential to offer a relaxed, get away from it all style resort, IF the management could get their act together and get the service to a consistently efficient level.

text: I have been to Sri Lanka on many occasions over the last 10 years, often combining work and leisure. My experience of Heritance hotels has been consistently good and Ahungalla was no exception. Access from the airport is also difficult, but when the Outer Circular opens, which will bypass Colombo, this will certainly alleviate most of the access difficulties. Despite this and overall, an excellent experience and while I don't visit down South that often, when I do, I shall definitely look to stay at Ahungalla in the future.
